titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Anne Morrow Lindbergh Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by John Dojka, Jane Thomson, Daphne Burt, Sheilah Conneen, Judith Schiff, and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:09

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, diaries, writings, childhood, school and college materials, housekeeping and social records, reports, memoranda and correspondence from the many organizations in which Anne Morrow Lindbergh took an active interest. Also included are voluminous mail from members of her reading public and memorabilia, both objects sent by admirers and items collected by her on her travels. The death of Charles Lindbergh in 1974 is documented by mail from friends, members of the public and organizations. Anne Morrow Lindbergh's writings make up the largest part of the papers and include her diaries (1929-1972, 1982-1988), drafts of her books, working notebooks, speeches, articles and stories, and published reviews of her work. Also in the papers are printed copies of her publications. Her personal correspondence with friends and family runs over many years. Correspondence with friends includes letters exchanged with Anne Carrel, Harry Guggenheim, Corliss Lamont, Harold and Nigel Nicolson, Vita Sackville-West, Igor Sikorsky, Truman and Katherine Smith, Helen and Kurt Wolff, Jean Stafford and Mary Ellen Chase. Her family correspondence contains letters exchanged by Anne Morrow Lindbergh and members of her immediate family as well as members of the Morrow, Lindbergh and Cutter families.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Anne M. Lindbergh and Charles A. Lindbergh, 1941-1988; gift of Reeve Lindbergh, 1998, 2003; gift of the Estate of Anne M. Lindbergh, 2001; gift of William A. Atchley, 2003; gift of Michiko Nakagawa, 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Accession 1989-M-063, box 13A, is closed to research until January 1, 2023.
Series II, box 67B, may only be used under the supervision of Public Services staff.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been assigned to Reeve Morrow Lindbergh by Anne Morrow Lindbergh for materials she authored or otherwise produced. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Anne Morrow Lindbergh Papers (MS 829). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials: Charles Augustus Lindbergh Papers (MS 325); Lindbergh Picture Collection (MS 325B); and Lindbergh Gift Collection (325A).
Associated materials: Anne Morrow Lindbergh Papers, Sophia Smith Collection at Smith College, Northampton, Massachusetts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Anne Morrow Lindbergh (1906 Jun 22 - 2001 Feb 7), author and aviator, was born Anne Spencer Morrow in Englewood, New Jersey, the daughter of Dwight W. Morrow, an investment banker, diplomat, and United States senator and Elizabeth Reeve Cutter, an educator. She had three siblings, Elisabeth, Dwight, Jr., and Constance. She was educated at Miss Chapin's School and Smith College. During her senior year she was introduced to Charles Augustus Lindbergh in December 1927 at the American Embassy in Mexico City where her father was serving as ambassador. They were married in a secret ceremony in May 1929 at her parents' estate in Englewood, New Jersey. She wanted to become a professional aviator and undertook an intense study of flying, radio theory, Morse code, and navigation, earning a pilot's license and setting a transcontinental speed record with her husband in 1930 when she was seven months pregnant. Anne Lindbergh was the first woman in the United States to obtain a glider pilot's license

In July 1931, the Lindberghs took off on an extended survey flight for Pan American Airways over the Arctic Circle in Canada to Japan and China. After the tragic kidnapping and murder of her son Charles Jr., in 1932, she took some comfort in narrating her experiences as co-pilot and navigator in her first book, North to the Orient , published in 1935. The memoir went on to win the National Book Award and launch a celebrated career. After the birth of their second son, Jon, they undertook a second air survey expedition through the North Atlantic spending a happy period of time in Greenland where they mapped the mountain ranges and took air samples. They then flew south through Europe to Africa returning across the South Atlantic to Brazil and north to New York. In 1934, the National Geographic Society recognized her forty thousand miles of exploration with its prestigious Hubbard Award. She was the first woman to receive it.

To protect their son Jon from intrusive publicity, the Lindberghs moved to England in 1935 after the kidnapping and murder trial of Bruno Hauptmann. In 1938 they moved to France to be near her husband's scientific colleague Alexis Carrel. During those years she wrote about their Atlantic expedition, first for National Geographic and in a second bestselling book, Listen! The Wind , published in 1938. In The Wave of the Future (1940), a book-length essay, she tried to interpret their non-interventionist position to the public. During World War II she was kept busy raising four children: Jon, Land, Scott, and Anne. While Charles worked on bomber development at the Ford factory, Anne found some time to study sculpting at the Cranbrook Academy of Art. Her last child, Reeve, was born in 1946. From the late 1940s through the 1960s, Anne Lindbergh published a large number of articles and poems in literary, women's, and general magazines on a variety of personal and international issues. She wrote about the importance of balancing personal needs, social expectations, and obligations to family and community in her most popular and enduring work, Gift from the Sea (1955). Next to the Bible it was the non-fiction best seller of the year and sold 430,000 copies. To date, well over eight million copies have been sold, and at least 30,000 copies are sold annually.

Anne Morrow Lindbergh was motivated to write an essay, "The Heron and the Astronaut," after the Lindberghs attended the Apollo 8 launch from the Kennedy Space Center on December 21, 1968, the astronauts' first flight into the orbit of the moon. It was published in 1969 under the title Earth Shine , with her essay on Africa, "Immersion in Life." The Lindberghs built a modest home in Hana, Maui, Hawaii in 1969-1970. Working with the Nature Conservancy, Anne and Charles Lindbergh made substantial contributions toward the purchase of land in the Valley of the Seven Sacred Pools in Maui to extend Haleakala National Park more than 4000 acres from the inland crater to the ocean. After her husband's death in 1974, she devoted much of her time to editing and publishing five volumes of her diaries and letters covering her life through the end of World War II.

Anne Morrow Lindbergh was enshrined in the National Aviation Hall of Fame July 21, 1979, "for outstanding contributions to aviation by her participation in pioneering flights surveying air routes to the Orient and Europe, and as an extraordinary author encouraging public appreciation of aviation and air travel." In the 1990s she moved from her home in Connecticut to her daughter Reeve's family farm in Vermont. Reeve Lindbergh dealt with the last seventeen months of her mother's life in the book No More Words , a sensitive and loving memoir of their time together, published in 2001. In 2012, the fourteenth book of her writings was published, Against Wind and Tide: Letters and Journals, 1947-1986 , based on her papers in Manuscripts and Archives.

Anne Morrow Lindbergh (1906 Jun 22 - 2001 Feb 7), author and aviator, was born Anne Spencer Morrow in Englewood, New Jersey, the daughter of Dwight W. Morrow, an investment banker, diplomat, and United States senator and Elizabeth Reeve Cutter, an educator. She had three siblings, Elisabeth, Dwight, Jr., and Constance. She was educated at Miss Chapin's School and Smith College. During her senior year she was introduced to Charles Augustus Lindbergh in December 1927 at the American Embassy in Mexico City where her father was serving as ambassador. They were married in a secret ceremony in May 1929 at her parents' estate in Englewood, New Jersey. She wanted to become a professional aviator and undertook an intense study of flying, radio theory, Morse code, and navigation, earning a pilot's license and setting a transcontinental speed record with her husband in 1930 when she was seven months pregnant. Anne Lindbergh was the first woman in the United States to obtain a glider pilot's license

In July 1931, the Lindberghs took off on an extended survey flight for Pan American Airways over the Arctic Circle in Canada to Japan and China. After the tragic kidnapping and murder of her son Charles Jr., in 1932, she took some comfort in narrating her experiences as co-pilot and navigator in her first book, North to the Orient , published in 1935. The memoir went on to win the National Book Award and launch a celebrated career. After the birth of their second son, Jon, they undertook a second air survey expedition through the North Atlantic spending a happy period of time in Greenland where they mapped the mountain ranges and took air samples. They then flew south through Europe to Africa returning across the South Atlantic to Brazil and north to New York. In 1934, the National Geographic Society recognized her forty thousand miles of exploration with its prestigious Hubbard Award. She was the first woman to receive it.

To protect their son Jon from intrusive publicity, the Lindberghs moved to England in 1935 after the kidnapping and murder trial of Bruno Hauptmann. In 1938 they moved to France to be near her husband's scientific colleague Alexis Carrel. During those years she wrote about their Atlantic expedition, first for National Geographic and in a second bestselling book, Listen! The Wind , published in 1938. In The Wave of the Future (1940), a book-length essay, she tried to interpret their non-interventionist position to the public. During World War II she was kept busy raising four children: Jon, Land, Scott, and Anne. While Charles worked on bomber development at the Ford factory, Anne found some time to study sculpting at the Cranbrook Academy of Art. Her last child, Reeve, was born in 1945. From the late 1940s through the 1960s, Anne Lindbergh published a large number of articles and poems in literary, women's, and general magazines on a variety of personal and international issues. She wrote about the importance of balancing personal needs, social expectations, and obligations to family and community in her most popular and enduring work, Gift from the Sea (1955). Next to the Bible, it was the non-fiction best seller of the year and sold 430,000 copies. To date, well over eight million copies have been sold, and at least 30,000 copies are sold annually.

Anne Morrow Lindbergh was motivated to write an essay, "The Heron and the Astronaut," after the Lindberghs attended the Apollo 8 launch from the Kennedy Space Center on December 21, 1968, the astronauts' first flight into the orbit of the moon. It was published in 1969 under the title Earth Shine , with her essay on Africa, "Immersion in Life." The Lindberghs built a modest home in Hana, Maui, Hawaii, in 1969-1970. Working with the Nature Conservancy, Anne and Charles Lindbergh made substantial contributions toward the purchase of land in the Valley of the Seven Sacred Pools in Maui to extend Haleakala National Park more than 4000 acres from the inland crater to the ocean. After her husband's death in 1974, she devoted much of her time to editing and publishing five volumes of her diaries and letters covering her life through the end of World War II.

Anne Morrow Lindbergh was enshrined in the National Aviation Hall of Fame July 21, 1979, "for outstanding contributions to aviation by her participation in pioneering flights surveying air routes to the Orient and Europe, and as an extraordinary author encouraging public appreciation of aviation and air travel." In the 1990s she moved from her home in Connecticut to her daughter Reeve's family farm in Vermont. Reeve Lindbergh dealt with the last seventeen months of her mother's life in the book No More Words , a sensitive and loving memoir of their time together, published in 2001. In 2012, the fourteenth book of her writings was published, Against Wind and Tide: Letters and Journals, 1947-1986 , based on her papers in Manuscripts and Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, diaries, writings, childhood, school and college materials, housekeeping and social records, reports, memoranda and correspondence from the many organizations in which Anne Morrow Lindbergh took an active interest. Also included is voluminous mail from members of her reading public and memorabilia, both objects sent by admirers and items collected by her on her travels. The death of Charles Lindbergh in 1974 is documented by mail from friends, members of the public and organizations. Anne Morrow Lindbergh's writings make up the largest part of the papers and include her diaries (1929-1972, 1982-1988), drafts of her books, working notebooks, speeches, articles and stories and published reviews of her work. Also in the papers are printed copies of her publications. Her personal correspondence with friends and family runs over many years. Correspondence with friends includes letters exchanged with Anne Carrel, Harry Guggenheim, Corliss Lamont, Harold and Nigel Nicolson, Vita Sackville-West, Igor Sikorsky, Truman and Katherine Smith, Helen and Kurt Wolff, Jean Stafford and Mary Ellen Chase. Her family correspondence contains letters exchanged by Anne Morrow Lindbergh and members of her immediate family as well as members of the Morrow, Lindbergh and Cutter families.

In the introduction to the first published volume of her diaries and letters, Bring Me a Unicorn , Anne Morrow Lindbergh noted that in the Morrow family "an experience was not finished, not truly experienced, unless written down or shared with another." This passion for committing experiences and events to writing is one of the unifying forces in Anne Morrow Lindbergh's life. Her personal papers are a rarity for a contemporary individual, in that they provide almost complete documentation for the entirety of her life.

Through her papers Anne Morrow Lindbergh can be studied from a number of perspectives: as a writer (diarist, poet, essayist, and novelist); social critic; pioneer aviator; conservationist; and mother, housekeeper, and wife of one of the century's most noted persons. Taken as a whole, the collection documents her continuing efforts at self realization.
Key to initials used by Anne Morrow Lindbergh, family, and friends in correspondence:
C: Before 1929 Constance Cutter Morrow; after 1929 Charles Augustus Lindbergh
CC: and CMM: Constance Cutter Morrow
DWM, Jr.: Dwight Whitney Morrow, Jr.
ECM: Elizabeth Cutter Morrow (Mrs. Dwight Morrow)
K: Kay Smith, Katherine Sullivan, Kitty Taquey

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in eleven series: I. Correspondence from friends and acquaintances, 1915-1973. II. Family correspondence and personal files, 1906-1974. III. Publishers' correspondence, 1930-1973. IV. General correspondence, 1916-1974. V. Correspondence from readers, 1934-1973. VI. Outgoing correspondence, 1920-1973. VII. Writings, 1919-1976. VIII. Housekeeping and social records, 1927-1974. IX. Institutions, committees, and clubs, 1934-1973. X. Childhood, school, and college, 1912-1928. XI. Memorabilia, 1920s-1970s; and subsequent additions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically. Letters of a particular correspondent are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of letters Lindbergh received from a large circle of friends and acquaintances. For Lindbergh's replies to the letters in this series, see the appropriate dates in Series VI, Outgoing correspondence.

By contemporary standards the correspondence is prolific and reveals the important role that friendship played in her life. Some of the people who corresponded with her from childhood on include Lucia (Norton) Valentine, Amy Aldrich, Vernon Munroe, Jr., Sue (Vaillant) Hatt, and Corliss Lamont. The correspondence of another childhood friend, Elizabeth "Dizzy' Hart, is of interest for the picture it gives of Anne Morrow Lindbergh as a school girl.

Major correspondents whose relationships with Lindbergh were particularly close and whose correspondence is voluminous include Dana Atchley, Ernestine (Stodelle) Chamberlain, Corliss Lamont, and Ruth (Thomas) Oliff. Other important correspondents include Dom Alexis (Abbot of Boquen), Anne Carrel (wife of Alexis Carrel), Harry Guggenheim, Harold and Nigel Nicolson,Vita Sackville-West, Igor Sikorsky, Truman and Katherine Smith, Eleanor and James Newton, Kitty Taquey, John Oldrin, and Helen and Kurt Wolff.

After college, Lindbergh remained in contact with two Smith College faculty members, Mina (Kirstein) Curtiss and Marthe Sturm. The correspondence from Curtiss is especially interesting because of the close friendship that developed between the former English professor and the writer.

Lindbergh corresponded with a number of artists, writers, and journalists. There is correspondence from Betsey Barton, Evelyn Ames, Jean Stafford, Sylvia Shaw Judson, Selden Rodman, Isabel La Follette, Russell Leffingwell, Lauren Dwight (Deac) Lyman, Carl Milles, Florida Scott-Maxwell, Mary Ellen Chase, and Stanley R. Ross.

America First activities are documented in correspondence from Kathleen Norris, Katrina Romney, Thelma Lee, and Sue (Vaillant) Hatt. Former employees (secretaries and children's nurses) with whom Lindbergh continued to correspond include Betty Gow, Felice Hankey, Gertrude Gloor, Judy Frautschi, Monte Millar, Marta (Brodie) Norris, Barbara Mansfield, Christine (Gawne) Wick, and Jean Saunders.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is divided into two sections: Family correspondence and Personal files. The former is arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent, with letters of a particular correspondent arranged chronologically. The material in Personal files is organized alphabetically by last name of family member.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Family correspondence contains letters exchanged by Anne Morrow Lindbergh and members of her immediate family (Charles and her children), members of the Morrow and Lindbergh families, and other relatives. Personal files include correspondence, legal and financial documents, writings, announcements, and newspaper clippings by or about various family members. For Morrow and Cutter family genealogical records, see the Charles A. Lindbergh Papers (MS 325), Series VI, Family correspondence and records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in three sections: Major publishers, Other publishers, and Publishers' announcements. Major publishers is arranged alphabetically by name of company, Other publishers and Publishers' announcements are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence in the series is incoming and runs from the time of the writing of "Flying Around the North Atlantic" (1934) to Hour of Gold, Hour of Lead (1973). Major publishers represented are Atlantic Monthly ; Harcourt, Brace; and Pantheon Books. Other Publishers files include correspondence from Common Sense , Harpers' Bazaar , Readers' Digest , Saturday Review of Literature , and other small publishing firms and magazines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of letters that fall into the following categories: personal letters from friends and acquaintances who wrote to Lindbergh fewer than five times; routine business correspondence; autograph requests; letters from the general public commenting on Lindbergh's activities; and requests that Lindbergh give speeches, serve on committees, and write articles on behalf of various religious, cultural, philanthropic, and political causes. Much of the correspondence in the series is routine. Viewed in its entirety, however, it reveals two aspects of Lindbergh's life. First, the close scrutiny to which her life, both public and private, was subjected to an intensely curious public, and second, her great influence and popularity as a writer with its corresponding demands on her time.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged chronologically by publication date of the work to which the letters pertain. For each work, letters are arranged into two groups: General, for persons unknown to Lindbergh, and Personal, for friends and family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains letters commenting on Lindbergh's writings. Works that elicited particularly voluminous correspondence are "Prayer for Peace" (1940), "Feeding Europe" (1940), The Wave of the Future (1940), Gift from the Sea (1955), and Bring Me a Unicorn (1971). Letters about "Feeding Europe" also include those that relate to the general question of sending relief to the occupied countries. Letters concerning the Lindberghs' stand on intervention in World War II are included under Wave of the Future .

The responses of readers to Lindbergh's work frequently center on the themes of mourning and recovery from personal loss; the role of a woman as wife, mother, and creative person; the loneliness and exhilaration of adolescence; and the individual's responsibility to act, whether as a peacemaker, conservationist, or artist. Although Lindbergh described her life as an "extraordinary" one led by "a quite ordinary person," it was her ability to convey the "ordinary," which allowed her readers to identify closely with her. She frequently placed an asterisk (*) on those letters which she termed "special." (For her replies to letters in this series, see the appropriate date in Series VI, Outgoing Correspondence).

unittitle.title: Hour of Gold, Hour of Lead

did.unittitle: Bring Me a Unicorn and Hour of Gold, Hour of Lead (general)
Reader comments on Anne Morrow Lindbergh's writings in general

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains typescripts, photocopies, and carbon copies of letters written by Lindbergh from 1920 to 1972, with the exception of letters written to her family, which are included in Series II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of research notes, outlines, drafts, and printed copies of the major portion of Lindbergh's published and unpublished writings. There are significant gaps, however, and it is not a complete collection of her notes and drafts for all of her writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in nine sections: Books; Articles and stories; Poems; Diaries; Notebooks; Speeches; Reviews of others' work and prefaces by Anne Morrow Lindbergh; Printed copies of Lindbergh's work; and Reviews and notices of Lindbergh's work. With two exceptions, the sections are arranged alphabetically by title. Diaries is organized chronologically by form, e.g. holograph original, typed copy, etc.; Printed copies of Lindbergh's work is arranged chronologically to illustrate the progression of her work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes engagement calendars and notes; address books and lists; planning materials for family vacations and Christmas celebrations; bills and receipts for routine household expenditures; advertisements for household furnishings and clothing saved by Lindbergh; and various business and financial records.

did.abstract: The series is arranged alphabetically by name of organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes correspondence, annual reports, and memoranda from philanthropic, educational, cultural, and social groups and organizations in which Lindbergh took an active interest or served as a board member. Of particular interest to her were the Elisabeth Morrow School, established by her sister and supported by the family after her death; Food and Parcels for Europe that aided needy families in post-war Europe; and the Institute of Direct Analysis.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The addition is arranged in ten sections: Correspondence from friends and acquaintances; Family correspondence and records; Correspondence with publishers: General correspondence; Correspondence from readers; Outgoing correspondence; Writings; Houskeeping and social records; Institutions, committees, and clubs; and Memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Headings in the addition correspond to titles of series from the main accession. In all of the correspondence, missing dates and names have been transcribed from the envelopes. Lindbergh annotated some letters "RU" for "request unanswered." Others are marked "Answer" or "To be answered," but Outgoing correspondence does not contain responses to all of these letters. The addition reflects the wide range of Lindbergh's activities and contacts in the period 1973-1976, but more than half concerns the death of her husband, Charles, in 1974. There are many sympathy cards and letters of condolence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The addition is arranged in ten sections: Correspondence from friends and acquaintances; Family correspondence and records; Correspondence with publishers; General correspondence; Correspondence with readers; Outgoing correspondence; Writings; Housekeeping and social records; Institutions, committees, and clubs; and Memorabilia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Headings in the addition correspond to series titles in the main accession. The addition contains some material concerning the death of Charles Augustus Lindbergh in 1974, but most of the papers reflect Anne Morrow Lindbergh's activities from 1976 to 1981, including her involvement with a variety of ceremonies commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of her husband's 1927 flight. Incoming correspondence is often annotated. Usually, annotations on general correspondence were made by the secretary, while annotations on personal correspondence were made by Lindbergh. Their abbreviations include "RA" and "RU," for "requests answered" and "requests unanswered," and "LVM" for "lost in volume of mail" (and therefore not answered). Not all drafts and carbons of outgoing correspondence are found under that heading. Some are filed with the letters to which they respond under Correspondence with readers. Materials related to fiftieth anniversary activities are found with the Charles A. Lindbergh Memorial Fund under Institutions, committees, and clubs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.
Copies of commercially produced audiovisual materials contained in this collection cannot be made for researcher use outside of the repository.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The addition consists of copies of popular magazines with articles primarily by Anne Morrow Lindbergh as well as a few by or about Charles Augustus Lindbergh, Jon Lindbergh, and Elizabeth Cutter Morrow (Anne's mother). The titles represented are The Atlantic Monthly , Collier's , Harper's Bazaar , Harper's Magazine , Life , National Geographic , nouveau femina , Reader's Digest , The Saturday Evening Post , This Week Magazine , Women's Home Journal , and Vogue .

The accession also includes a helmet and goggles belonging to Anne.
